episodeTitle: A Rift Opens Up! Luffy vs. Jimbei!
description: Luffy and Jinbe clash over who should fight Hody Jones, with Jinbe insisting that human involvement would worsen Fish-Man Island's racial tensions. Meanwhile, Brook demonstrates his new ability to separate his soul from his body, and the captured Straw Hats devise an escape plan.

events.title: Luffy vs Jinbe Duel Begins
events.description: Luffy and Jinbe begin their confrontation to determine who has the right to fight Hody Jones. Jinbe insists that if humans get involved in defeating Hody, it will perpetuate the cycle of hatred between humans and fish-men on Fish-Man Island.
events.significance: This conflict highlights the complex racial tensions on Fish-Man Island and demonstrates the moral complexity of the arc. It shows Jinbe's understanding of how Fish-Man Island's history affects current events.

quotes.text: If humans get involved, the people of Fish-Man Island will see humans as a violent race!
quotes.speaker: Jinbe
quotes.context: Jinbe explaining why Luffy shouldn't fight Hody Jones

events.title: Fish-Man Karate's True Nature Explained
events.description: Jinbe demonstrates Fish-Man Karate on Luffy, explaining that it manipulates the water within all living things. Since humans are 70% water, being struck by a Fish-Man Karate master like Jinbe can hurt even a rubber man like Luffy.
events.significance: This revelation explains how Fish-Man Karate can bypass Luffy's rubber immunity, establishing it as a legitimate threat and demonstrating the unique properties of this martial art.

quotes.text: Fish-Man Karate is about manipulating the water all around you. As all humans are 70% water, being punched by a master like me would not be a pleasant experience.
quotes.speaker: Jinbe
quotes.context: Explaining why his attacks can hurt Luffy despite him being made of rubber

events.title: Robin's Cuerpo Fleur Technique Debut
events.description: As Luffy activates Gear Second and prepares to clash with Jinbe, Robin intervenes using her new post-timeskip technique Cuerpo Fleur. She creates a full-body clone of herself to stop the fight, while her real body emerges from the forest unharmed.
events.significance: This is the first demonstration of Robin's enhanced Hana Hana no Mi abilities after the timeskip, showing she can now create complete body duplicates rather than just sprouting individual body parts.

quotes.text: I've learned how to make clones of myself.
quotes.speaker: Robin
quotes.context: Revealing her new technique after stopping the fight

events.title: Brook's Soul Separation Ability Revealed
events.description: Brook demonstrates his newly discovered ability to separate his soul from his skeletal body using the Yomi Yomi no Mi's true power. His soul appears as a spectral skeletal face engulfed in spiritual flames, shocking Usopp and Zoro. Brook reveals he discovered this ability while praying during a low point in his musical career.
events.significance: This reveals the true potential of the Yomi Yomi no Mi beyond just resurrection, establishing Brook's soul manipulation powers that will become important in future arcs. It also adds a comedic element when Brook admits to using it for perverted purposes.

quotes.text: I learned this trick from praying one day and have been using its power to peek on girls.
quotes.speaker: Brook
quotes.context: Explaining how he discovered and has been using his soul separation ability

events.title: Captured Straw Hats Plan Their Escape
events.description: With Hody Jones and the New Fish-Man Pirates moving out to Gyoncorde Plaza, the captured Straw Hats (Zoro, Usopp, and Brook) begin plotting their escape from Ryugu Palace using Brook's new soul separation ability.
events.significance: This sets up the Straw Hats' escape and reunion, moving the arc toward its climactic confrontation at Gyoncorde Plaza.

events.title: Hody Jones Moves Forces to Gyoncorde Plaza
events.description: Hody Jones orders all his New Fish-Man Pirates forces to move out from Ryugu Palace to Gyoncorde Plaza, along with the residents of the Fish-Man District. This strategic repositioning sets the stage for a public execution and demonstration of power.
events.significance: This relocation establishes Gyoncorde Plaza as the central battleground for the arc's climax and demonstrates Hody's intention to make a public spectacle of his takeover.

events.title: Luffy and Jinbe's Fight Interrupted
events.description: The duel between Luffy and Jinbe is cut short when Sanji tries to save Robin's clone, resulting in Luffy, Jinbe, and Sanji accidentally hitting each other instead. This comedic interruption temporarily ends their philosophical conflict.
events.significance: While played for comedy, this moment shows that the Straw Hats and their allies can work together despite disagreements, foreshadowing their eventual unified front against Hody Jones.

quotes.text: If humans get involved, the people of Fish-Man Island will see humans as a violent race!
quotes.speaker: Jinbe
quotes.context: Explaining to Luffy why he must not fight Hody Jones

quotes.text: Fish-Man Karate is about manipulating the water all around you. As all humans are 70% water, being punched by a master like me would not be a pleasant experience.
quotes.speaker: Jinbe
quotes.context: Explaining how Fish-Man Karate can hurt Luffy

quotes.text: I've learned how to make clones of myself.
quotes.speaker: Robin
quotes.context: Revealing her new Cuerpo Fleur technique

quotes.text: I learned this trick from praying one day and have been using its power to peek on girls.
quotes.speaker: Brook
quotes.context: Admitting his perverted use of soul separation

themes.theme: Racial Prejudice and Cycle of Hatred
themes.description: The episode deeply explores the racial tensions between humans and fish-men, with Jinbe arguing that human intervention in Fish-Man Island's problems will only perpetuate hatred and prejudice.
themes.symbolism: Luffy and Jinbe's fight represents the clash between immediate action and long-term social healing, embodying the complex moral questions at the heart of the Fish-Man Island arc.

themes.description: The Straw Hats demonstrate their post-timeskip growth through new techniques like Robin's Cuerpo Fleur and Brook's soul separation, showing the fruits of their two-year training.
themes.symbolism: The new abilities symbolize personal growth and evolution, proving the crew is ready for the New World's challenges.

themes.description: Luffy and Jinbe's disagreement highlights different approaches to justice - Luffy's direct action versus Jinbe's consideration of broader social consequences.
themes.symbolism: Their conflict represents the tension between individual justice and societal healing.

characterSpotlights.development: Jinbe's deep understanding of Fish-Man Island's racial history is explored, showing his wisdom and concern for long-term peace over immediate victory.
keyActions: Confronts Luffy about fighting Hody Jones
Explains the nature of Fish-Man Karate and why it can hurt Luffy
quotes: If humans get involved, the people of Fish-Man Island will see humans as a violent race!

characterSpotlights.development: Robin showcases her enhanced Devil Fruit mastery with the debut of Cuerpo Fleur, demonstrating the results of her two-year training.
keyActions: Creates a full-body clone to stop Luffy and Jinbe's fight
quotes: I've learned how to make clones of myself.

characterSpotlights.development: Brook reveals the true potential of the Yomi Yomi no Mi, showing his soul manipulation abilities while maintaining his perverted personality.
keyActions: Separates his soul from his skeleton body
Shocks Zoro and Usopp with his spectral form
Admits to using the ability for perverted purposes
Helps plan the escape from Ryugu Palace
quotes: I learned this trick from praying one day and have been using its power to peek on girls.

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime expanded Brook's backstory, adding a scene explaining that he discovered his soul separation ability while praying during a slump in his musical career.
In the manga, only Nami cries out for Robin when she interferes with the fight. In the anime, both Nami and Chopper cry out for Robin.
The scene with Shirahoshi and Camie watching with worry, and Sanji's lovestruck reaction to Robin's intervention was added in the anime.
The scene with Pappag and Brook's spirit form was elaborated beyond what was shown in the manga.

trivia.fact: This episode adapts Chapter 629, pages 2-14 and 18-19, making it one of the more efficiently paced episodes during the Fish-Man Island arc.

The opening theme 'We Go!' by Hiroshi Kitadani was created by the same 'Golden Team' (writer Shoko Fujibayashi, composer Kohei Tanaka, arranger Takayuki Negishi) that created the first One Piece opening 'We Are!'

sources.title: We Go! | One Piece Wiki | Fandom

trivia.fact: Brook's soul color was shown as green in both the manga volume 64 cover and this episode, establishing visual consistency between the two mediums.
This episode aired during a period when One Piece had no ending themes (episodes 279-1070), using instead a 'We Go!' remix for the next episode preview.

sources.title: One Piece Music | One Piece Wiki | Fandom

trivia.fact: The episode received an 8.8% TV rating in Japan and ranked 6th for its time slot.
Katsuhisa Hoki took over the role of Jinbe from the late Daisuke Gori, who passed away in 2010. This was Hoki's established performance as Jinbe after the timeskip.
